## Recorded talks

### L’expérience sensible du monde
**Nicolas Rougier | TEDxQuartierLatin** (2024, 12:29, [Watch on YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6yl_j5g9Mj8))

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}
[![L’expérience sensible du monde](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/6yl_j5g9Mj8/mqdefault.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6yl_j5g9Mj8)
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}
**Abstract:** Researcher Nicolas Rougier discusses the limitations of AI by emphasizing the "sensitive experience of the world." He explains that while AI like ChatGPT can manipulate symbols, it lacks the physical embodiment and sensory interaction necessary for true conceptual understanding.
:::
:::



### Modern and Interactive Scientific Visualization
**Nicolas P. Rougier | X.Org Foundation** (2014, 22:20, [Watch on YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ms3i5hAvOY0))

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}
[![Modern and Interactive Scientific Visualization](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Ms3i5hAvOY0/mqdefault.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ms3i5hAvOY0)
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}
**Abstract:** Nicolas Rougier presents his work on bridging the gap between high-quality scientific plotting (like Matplotlib) and high-performance GPU rendering. He demonstrates techniques using Python and OpenGL to achieve anti-aliased text, complex paths, and large-scale data visualization (up to millions of points) while maintaining aesthetic quality. The talk introduces the **VisPy** and **glumpy** projects as unified frameworks for modern scientific visualization.
:::
:::


### Le rôle des corps dans la cognition
**Nicolas Rougier | Cognivence Paris** (2014, 01:05:33, [Watch on YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fqqGQhKvDj8))

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}
[![Le rôle des corps dans la cognition](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/fqqGQhKvDj8/mqdefault.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fqqGQhKvDj8)
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}

**Abstract:** Dans cette conférence donnée lors de la Semaine du Cerveau, Nicolas Rougier explore le concept de **cognition incarnée**. Il explique comment l'intelligence n'est pas simplement une manipulation de symboles abstraits, mais qu'elle est intimement liée à la forme physique et aux interactions sensorielles du corps avec son environnement.
:::
:::

### ReScience Initiative
**Nicolas Rougier & Konrad Hinsen | EuroSciPy 2015** (2015, 15:30, [Watch on YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=orLYVhSrOwk))

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}
[![ReScience Initiative](https://i.ytimg.com/vi/orLYVhSrOwk/mqdefault.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=orLYVhSrOwk)
:::

::: {.column width="5%"}
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}

**Abstract:** Nicolas Rougier introduces **ReScience**, a peer-reviewed journal hosted on GitHub dedicated to the replication of computational research. He highlights the "reproducibility crisis" in science, where ambiguous paper descriptions and inaccessible source code (often in obsolete languages) make it nearly impossible to verify results.
:::

:::
